title: How to Fix Your Oven

steps.headline: Switch off the breaker to the oven and unplug it.
steps.description: The first thing you need to do before you work on an electric oven is to turn off the power to it. Unplug the oven’s cord from the wall outlet and go to the circuit breaker and find the breaker that controls the flow of electricity to the oven. Switch it to the “Off” position to cut off power to the oven. If the circuit breaker doesn’t have a switch for the oven, shut off the breaker to the kitchen. If there is more than 1 breaker for the oven, flip them both to the “Off” position.

steps.headline: Take off the panel covering the heating element.
steps.description: Some ovens have a metal panel at the bottom of the oven that covers and protects the heating element. Check for a lip on the front edge of the panel, lift it up, and pull it out of the oven. You may need to push down on a corner of the panel to raise up another corner that you can then grab to remove the panel.

steps.headline: Unscrew the screws on the fasteners holding the element.
steps.description: The element will have 2 fasteners at the front and 1 at the rear of the oven that keeps the element held in place. Loosen and remove the screws that connect the fasteners to the oven. If the element is push-fit in the oven, and doesn’t have any screws, you can pull the element straight out of its connection point. Keep the screws nearby so you don’t lose them.

steps.headline: Disconnect the wires connected to the element at the rear of the oven.
steps.description: At the rear wall of the oven, there are 2 colored wires that provide electricity to the heating element. Detach the 2 wires, making sure the wires don’t fall through the holes in the back and get stuck behind the oven.Tip: Use a pair of needle-nosed pliers if you’re having trouble disconnecting the wires with your fingers.

steps.headline: Remove the faulty heating element from the oven.
steps.description: After the element has been completely disconnected, pull it out from the oven and inspect it for a make and model identification. This will help you find the exact same element as a replacement.

steps.headline: Insert a new element and reconnect the wires.
steps.description: Replace the element with the exact same make and model and fit it into the oven. Reattach the terminal wires at the rear of the oven. Connect them the same way they were connected to the faulty element. Consider taking the faulty element with you if you purchase a replacement from a hardware store.

steps.headline: Screw the fasteners to the element.
steps.description: Once the new element has been fitted into the oven and the wires reconnected, reconnect the fasteners to the element. Screw them down at the same locations and using the same screws as the previous element. Be sure to tighten the screws so they hold the element securely. Don’t screw the screws in so far that they crack or bend the element.

steps.headline: Turn on the power and test the element by turning on the oven.
steps.description: After the new element has been secured, plug the oven back into the wall outlet. Then, return the flow of power by switching the breaker back on. Finally, turn on the oven to test that the new heating element is working. Hold your hand over the element to feel if it is heating up.

steps.headline: Put on work gloves to protect your hands.
steps.description: A good pair of thick work gloves will improve your grip and keep your hands safe. Before you start to disassemble or repair your oven, be sure to put on a pair of well-fitted gloves. Rubber gloves can tear and don’t provide as much protection as work gloves will.

steps.headline: Unplug the oven and shut off the gas supply.
steps.description: The range of the gas oven needs to be unplugged to prevent the risk of electrocution. Locate the gas line in the wall behind the oven and turn the valve to the “Off” position to cut off the flow of gas to the oven so you can work safely. Some plugs require you to press a release button to unplug it from the outlet.

steps.headline: Take out the oven racks.
steps.description: You need to have plenty of room to maneuver inside of the oven while you’re fixing it. Slide all of the oven racks out of the oven and set them aside so you can reach every section of the oven. Use the opportunity to clean the oven racks.

steps.headline: Unscrew the screws at the rear of the bottom oven panel.
steps.description: Look for a set of screws that attach the panel on the floor of the oven. Use a screwdriver or drill to remove the screws. You may need to use an Allen wrench to remove the screws.

steps.headline: Lift the back of the panel and remove it from the oven.
steps.description: The oven may have a lip on the front that helps to hold the panel in place. Raise the rear section of the panel and push it back slightly so you can lift the panel and pull it out of the oven. Some ovens may have screws in the front of the panel that need to be removed in order to extract it.

steps.headline: Remove the screws from the bracket holding the igniter.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the bottom panel, you’ll see the igniter held in place at the rear of the oven. The igniter is supported by brackets that are screwed in. Unscrew the screws and separate the brackets from the oven to dislodge the igniter.Tip: Keep the screws nearby so you don’t lose them.

steps.headline: Unplug the wire harness from the igniter and remove it.
steps.description: After you’ve dislodged the brackets, you’ll be able to see the wire harness that is connected to the igniter and provides electricity to it. Pull the igniter out a little bit so you can get a good grip on the wire harness and unplug the cords. Then, pull the igniter out of the oven.

steps.headline: Plug the new igniter into the wire harness and insert the mounting screws.
steps.description: Make sure the wires are attached securely and the igniter is in the same position as the faulty one that was removed. Hold the igniter in place and attach the brackets by screwing in the screws.

steps.headline: Replace the bottom panel and install the screws to hold it in place.
steps.description: Insert the front of the panel beneath the lip at the front of the bottom of the oven. Then, lower the rear section of the panel back into place. Insert the screws to hold the panel in place. Be sure to tighten the screws so the panel is secure.

steps.headline: Plug in the oven and turn on the gas supply.
steps.description: Now that the igniter has been replaced, plug in the gas range into the wall outlet. Turn the dial on the gas supply to the “On” position. If you had to move the oven to access the outlet and gas supply, return the oven back to its original position.

steps.headline: Turn the oven on to test that it’s working.
steps.description: After you’ve restored power and the flow of gas to your gas oven, set the oven to a bake setting. Use your hand to feel if the oven is heating up to confirm that the replaced igniter is functioning. If the oven still doesn’t work, there may be an issue with the gas line, which requires a certified technician to repair.

steps.headline: Unplug the oven before you begin to work on it.
steps.description: The range of the oven and the thermostat use electricity to function. To avoid the risk of accidental electrocution, make sure you unplug the oven before you do anything else. The cord will be located behind the oven, so you may need to slide or pull the oven away from the wall to access it.

steps.headline: Use a 6 in (15 cm) length of string to pry off the thermostat knob.
steps.description: If your oven has a knob that controls the thermostat, you need to remove it in order to replace the thermostat. Use some string to slide beneath the knob, keep the string tight, and pry off the knob. Don’t snap or jerk the knob off or you could damage it. Keep the thermostat knob nearby so you can replace it when you’re finished.

steps.headline: Remove the screws from the upper back panel of the oven.
steps.description: On the backside of the oven are panels that keep the internal components protected. You need to remove the upper panel in order to access the faulty thermostat. Locate the screws that hold the panel in place and remove them with a screwdriver. Do not lose the screws! Keep them nearby so you can put them back after you finish replacing the thermostat.

steps.headline: Pull the upper panel off of the oven.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the screws, allow the upper panel to lean off of the oven so you can grip it with your hands. Lift the panel up and pull it away from the oven. Use the opportunity to clean and wipe down the panel while you have it removed. Place the panel nearby so you don’t lose it.

steps.headline: Unscrew the mounting screws from the thermostat and remove it.
steps.description: If your oven has a thermostat knob, after you remove it, you’ll see 2 or 3 screws that keep the thermostat held in place. Unscrew them with a screwdriver and remove the old thermostat from the back of the oven.Tip: Have another person hold the thermostat in place while you unscrew it from the front.

steps.headline: Install the new thermostat and screw it into place.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the faulty thermostat, place the new one in the same position as the old one. Screw in the mounting screws to hold the new thermostat in place. Don’t screw them so tight that they crack the mounts. Wiggle the new thermostat to make sure it’s secure. It shouldn’t move at all.

steps.headline: Transfer the wires from the old thermostat to the replacement.
steps.description: With the new thermostat in place, pull out the wires from the old one and insert them in the same place on the new one. Make sure they fit securely into the ports. Some thermostats have clamps over the ports that you need to pinch open to insert the wires.

steps.headline: Unclip the old sensor and slide it out of the back of the oven.
steps.description: Inside of the oven, there is a sensor bulb on the back wall. Unclip it from the supports holding it in place and route it through the back of the oven. Remove it from behind the oven.

steps.headline: Route the replacement sensor and clip it into position.
steps.description: From the back of the oven, insert the new sensor bulb where you removed the old one. Route the bulb to the inside of the oven. Snap it back into the clips to hold it in place.

steps.headline: Replace the back panel and thermostat knob.
steps.description: Put the upper back panel back to its original position and screw it into place. Then, clip the thermostat knob back on if your oven has one. It should “click” when it’s securely attached. Turn the knob back and forth a few times to make sure it fits correctly.

steps.headline: Plug the oven back in and turn it on.
steps.description: With the new thermostat and sensor bulb installed, you can restore power to the control panel by plugging the oven back in and sliding it back into position. Test the new thermostat Test the new thermostat by turning the oven on to a specific temperature and placing an oven thermometer into the oven. If the thermostat still isn’t working, there may be a deeper issue. Call a technician to repair your oven.

steps.headline: Cut off the power and turn off the gas before you work.
steps.description: Before you make any repairs on an oven, it’s very important that you eliminate the risk of electrocution or exposure to toxic gases. Unplug your oven and shut off the gas valve if you have a gas oven. Slide the oven away from the wall to unplug the cord and to allow you to access the rear of the oven.

steps.headline: Open the oven door and engage the locking mechanism.
steps.description: Pull the handle to open the oven door all the way. Look for a bracket near the hinge of the door. Flick or swivel the bracket into position so the oven door remains open at a 45-degree angle. Open the door all the way to engage the lock, then close the oven door until the locking mechanism prevents you from closing it.

steps.headline: Lift the oven door straight up to remove it.
steps.description: With the lock engaged and the door at a 45-degree angle, grab the sides of the oven with your hands. Gently slide the oven door straight up to remove it from the hinges. Pull the door out of the oven. Be careful not to drop the oven door or it break.

steps.headline: Place the door on a flat surface to work on.
steps.description: It will be much easier for you to access the hinges and work on the oven door if you lay it flat on a table or a desk. Clear the area so you can work unimpeded. Lay down a towel or newspaper to prevent the door from scratching the surface.

steps.headline: Remove the screws from around the hinges and the side of the door.
steps.description: There are 4 screws around each hinge that need to be removed. You also need to remove the screws along the sides, top, and center of the door. Be careful as you remove the screws because the door will start to come apart. You don’t want to lose any pieces. Keep all of the screws together so you don’t lose any of them.

steps.headline: Lift and remove the inner panel of the door.
steps.description: Push the hinges up to raise the inner panel so you can get a grip on it with your hands. Raise the inner panel to separate and remove it.

steps.headline: Pull out the hinges from each side of the door.
steps.description: Lift up the internal panel of the door just enough for you to grab the hinge. Gently slide the hinges out from the door and set them aside. You may be able to scrap or sell the faulty hinges to a hardware store.

steps.headline: Place the new hinges in the channels.
steps.description: After you’ve pulled out the old hinges, gently raise up the internal panel and insert the new hinges into the channels that held the old hinges. They should fit neatly into place. Lower the panel back down over the hinges. Make sure you put the left and right hinges in the correct sides of the oven door.

steps.headline: Replace the inner door panel and replace all of the screws.
steps.description: With the new hinges installed, put the door back together by lining up the inner panel and screwing it back into place. Put the screws that were around the hinges back into place as well to secure the hinges. Be sure to place the correct screws in the correct slots or it could weaken the integrity of the door. Screw the panels together tightly so the door is held together securely.

steps.headline: Line up the hinge with the metal bracket of the oven and replace the door.
steps.description: To replace the door on the oven, look for little notches on the hinges. Line up the notches with the brackets on the oven and fit them into place. Close the oven door to reattach it. Open and close the oven door a few times to make sure it’s correctly aligned.

text: Replacing an Electric Heating Element Switch off the breaker to the oven and unplug it. The first thing you need to do before you work on an electric oven is to turn off the power to it. Unplug the oven’s cord from the wall outlet and go to the circuit breaker and find the breaker that controls the flow of electricity to the oven. Switch it to the “Off” position to cut off power to the oven. If the circuit breaker doesn’t have a switch for the oven, shut off the breaker to the kitchen. If there is more than 1 breaker for the oven, flip them both to the “Off” position. Take off the panel covering the heating element. Some ovens have a metal panel at the bottom of the oven that covers and protects the heating element. Check for a lip on the front edge of the panel, lift it up, and pull it out of the oven. You may need to push down on a corner of the panel to raise up another corner that you can then grab to remove the panel. Unscrew the screws on the fasteners holding the element. The element will have 2 fasteners at the front and 1 at the rear of the oven that keeps the element held in place. Loosen and remove the screws that connect the fasteners to the oven. If the element is push-fit in the oven, and doesn’t have any screws, you can pull the element straight out of its connection point. Keep the screws nearby so you don’t lose them. Disconnect the wires connected to the element at the rear of the oven. At the rear wall of the oven, there are 2 colored wires that provide electricity to the heating element. Detach the 2 wires, making sure the wires don’t fall through the holes in the back and get stuck behind the oven.Tip: Use a pair of needle-nosed pliers if you’re having trouble disconnecting the wires with your fingers. Remove the faulty heating element from the oven. After the element has been completely disconnected, pull it out from the oven and inspect it for a make and model identification. This will help you find the exact same element as a replacement. Insert a new element and reconnect the wires. Replace the element with the exact same make and model and fit it into the oven. Reattach the terminal wires at the rear of the oven. Connect them the same way they were connected to the faulty element. Consider taking the faulty element with you if you purchase a replacement from a hardware store. Screw the fasteners to the element. Once the new element has been fitted into the oven and the wires reconnected, reconnect the fasteners to the element. Screw them down at the same locations and using the same screws as the previous element. Be sure to tighten the screws so they hold the element securely. Don’t screw the screws in so far that they crack or bend the element. Turn on the power and test the element by turning on the oven. After the new element has been secured, plug the oven back into the wall outlet. Then, return the flow of power by switching the breaker back on. Finally, turn on the oven to test that the new heating element is working. Hold your hand over the element to feel if it is heating up. Installing a New Gas Igniter Put on work gloves to protect your hands. A good pair of thick work gloves will improve your grip and keep your hands safe. Before you start to disassemble or repair your oven, be sure to put on a pair of well-fitted gloves. Rubber gloves can tear and don’t provide as much protection as work gloves will. Unplug the oven and shut off the gas supply. The range of the gas oven needs to be unplugged to prevent the risk of electrocution. Locate the gas line in the wall behind the oven and turn the valve to the “Off” position to cut off the flow of gas to the oven so you can work safely. Some plugs require you to press a release button to unplug it from the outlet. Take out the oven racks. You need to have plenty of room to maneuver inside of the oven while you’re fixing it. Slide all of the oven racks out of the oven and set them aside so you can reach every section of the oven. Use the opportunity to clean the oven racks. Unscrew the screws at the rear of the bottom oven panel. Look for a set of screws that attach the panel on the floor of the oven. Use a screwdriver or drill to remove the screws. You may need to use an Allen wrench to remove the screws. Lift the back of the panel and remove it from the oven. The oven may have a lip on the front that helps to hold the panel in place. Raise the rear section of the panel and push it back slightly so you can lift the panel and pull it out of the oven. Some ovens may have screws in the front of the panel that need to be removed in order to extract it. Remove the screws from the bracket holding the igniter. Once you’ve removed the bottom panel, you’ll see the igniter held in place at the rear of the oven. The igniter is supported by brackets that are screwed in. Unscrew the screws and separate the brackets from the oven to dislodge the igniter.Tip: Keep the screws nearby so you don’t lose them. Unplug the wire harness from the igniter and remove it. After you’ve dislodged the brackets, you’ll be able to see the wire harness that is connected to the igniter and provides electricity to it. Pull the igniter out a little bit so you can get a good grip on the wire harness and unplug the cords. Then, pull the igniter out of the oven. Plug the new igniter into the wire harness and insert the mounting screws. Make sure the wires are attached securely and the igniter is in the same position as the faulty one that was removed. Hold the igniter in place and attach the brackets by screwing in the screws. Replace the bottom panel and install the screws to hold it in place. Insert the front of the panel beneath the lip at the front of the bottom of the oven. Then, lower the rear section of the panel back into place. Insert the screws to hold the panel in place. Be sure to tighten the screws so the panel is secure. Plug in the oven and turn on the gas supply. Now that the igniter has been replaced, plug in the gas range into the wall outlet. Turn the dial on the gas supply to the “On” position. If you had to move the oven to access the outlet and gas supply, return the oven back to its original position. Turn the oven on to test that it’s working. After you’ve restored power and the flow of gas to your gas oven, set the oven to a bake setting. Use your hand to feel if the oven is heating up to confirm that the replaced igniter is functioning. If the oven still doesn’t work, there may be an issue with the gas line, which requires a certified technician to repair. Replacing an Oven Thermostat Unplug the oven before you begin to work on it. The range of the oven and the thermostat use electricity to function. To avoid the risk of accidental electrocution, make sure you unplug the oven before you do anything else. The cord will be located behind the oven, so you may need to slide or pull the oven away from the wall to access it. Use a 6 in (15 cm) length of string to pry off the thermostat knob. If your oven has a knob that controls the thermostat, you need to remove it in order to replace the thermostat. Use some string to slide beneath the knob, keep the string tight, and pry off the knob. Don’t snap or jerk the knob off or you could damage it. Keep the thermostat knob nearby so you can replace it when you’re finished. Remove the screws from the upper back panel of the oven. On the backside of the oven are panels that keep the internal components protected. You need to remove the upper panel in order to access the faulty thermostat. Locate the screws that hold the panel in place and remove them with a screwdriver. Do not lose the screws! Keep them nearby so you can put them back after you finish replacing the thermostat. Pull the upper panel off of the oven. Once you’ve removed the screws, allow the upper panel to lean off of the oven so you can grip it with your hands. Lift the panel up and pull it away from the oven. Use the opportunity to clean and wipe down the panel while you have it removed. Place the panel nearby so you don’t lose it. Unscrew the mounting screws from the thermostat and remove it. If your oven has a thermostat knob, after you remove it, you’ll see 2 or 3 screws that keep the thermostat held in place. Unscrew them with a screwdriver and remove the old thermostat from the back of the oven.Tip: Have another person hold the thermostat in place while you unscrew it from the front. Install the new thermostat and screw it into place. Once you’ve removed the faulty thermostat, place the new one in the same position as the old one. Screw in the mounting screws to hold the new thermostat in place. Don’t screw them so tight that they crack the mounts. Wiggle the new thermostat to make sure it’s secure. It shouldn’t move at all. Transfer the wires from the old thermostat to the replacement. With the new thermostat in place, pull out the wires from the old one and insert them in the same place on the new one. Make sure they fit securely into the ports. Some thermostats have clamps over the ports that you need to pinch open to insert the wires. Unclip the old sensor and slide it out of the back of the oven. Inside of the oven, there is a sensor bulb on the back wall. Unclip it from the supports holding it in place and route it through the back of the oven. Remove it from behind the oven. Route the replacement sensor and clip it into position. From the back of the oven, insert the new sensor bulb where you removed the old one. Route the bulb to the inside of the oven. Snap it back into the clips to hold it in place. Replace the back panel and thermostat knob. Put the upper back panel back to its original position and screw it into place. Then, clip the thermostat knob back on if your oven has one. It should “click” when it’s securely attached. Turn the knob back and forth a few times to make sure it fits correctly. Plug the oven back in and turn it on. With the new thermostat and sensor bulb installed, you can restore power to the control panel by plugging the oven back in and sliding it back into position. Test the new thermostat Test the new thermostat by turning the oven on to a specific temperature and placing an oven thermometer into the oven. If the thermostat still isn’t working, there may be a deeper issue. Call a technician to repair your oven. Repairing an Oven Door Cut off the power and turn off the gas before you work. Before you make any repairs on an oven, it’s very important that you eliminate the risk of electrocution or exposure to toxic gases. Unplug your oven and shut off the gas valve if you have a gas oven. Slide the oven away from the wall to unplug the cord and to allow you to access the rear of the oven. Open the oven door and engage the locking mechanism. Pull the handle to open the oven door all the way. Look for a bracket near the hinge of the door. Flick or swivel the bracket into position so the oven door remains open at a 45-degree angle. Open the door all the way to engage the lock, then close the oven door until the locking mechanism prevents you from closing it. Lift the oven door straight up to remove it. With the lock engaged and the door at a 45-degree angle, grab the sides of the oven with your hands. Gently slide the oven door straight up to remove it from the hinges. Pull the door out of the oven. Be careful not to drop the oven door or it break. Place the door on a flat surface to work on. It will be much easier for you to access the hinges and work on the oven door if you lay it flat on a table or a desk. Clear the area so you can work unimpeded. Lay down a towel or newspaper to prevent the door from scratching the surface. Remove the screws from around the hinges and the side of the door. There are 4 screws around each hinge that need to be removed. You also need to remove the screws along the sides, top, and center of the door. Be careful as you remove the screws because the door will start to come apart. You don’t want to lose any pieces. Keep all of the screws together so you don’t lose any of them. Lift and remove the inner panel of the door. Push the hinges up to raise the inner panel so you can get a grip on it with your hands. Raise the inner panel to separate and remove it. Pull out the hinges from each side of the door. Lift up the internal panel of the door just enough for you to grab the hinge. Gently slide the hinges out from the door and set them aside. You may be able to scrap or sell the faulty hinges to a hardware store. Place the new hinges in the channels. After you’ve pulled out the old hinges, gently raise up the internal panel and insert the new hinges into the channels that held the old hinges. They should fit neatly into place. Lower the panel back down over the hinges. Make sure you put the left and right hinges in the correct sides of the oven door. Replace the inner door panel and replace all of the screws. With the new hinges installed, put the door back together by lining up the inner panel and screwing it back into place. Put the screws that were around the hinges back into place as well to secure the hinges. Be sure to place the correct screws in the correct slots or it could weaken the integrity of the door. Screw the panels together tightly so the door is held together securely. Line up the hinge with the metal bracket of the oven and replace the door. To replace the door on the oven, look for little notches on the hinges. Line up the notches with the brackets on the oven and fit them into place. Close the oven door to reattach it. Open and close the oven door a few times to make sure it’s correctly aligned.

The first thing you need to do before you work on an electric oven is to turn off the power to it.

Switch it to the “Off” position to cut off power to the oven.
If the circuit breaker doesn’t have a switch for the oven, shut off the breaker to the kitchen.
If there is more than 1 breaker for the oven, flip them both to the “Off” position.

The element will have 2 fasteners at the front and 1 at the rear of the oven that keeps the element held in place.
Loosen and remove the screws that connect the fasteners to the oven.
If the element is push-fit in the oven, and doesn’t have any screws, you can pull the element straight out of its connection point.
Keep the screws nearby so you don’t lose them.

At the rear wall of the oven, there are 2 colored wires that provide electricity to the heating element.

Detach the 2 wires, making sure the wires don’t fall through the holes in the back and get stuck behind the oven.Tip: Use a pair of needle-nosed pliers if you’re having trouble disconnecting the wires with your fingers.

After the element has been completely disconnected, pull it out from the oven and inspect it for a make and model identification.
This will help you find the exact same element as a replacement.
Insert a new element and reconnect the wires.

Screw the fasteners to the element.
Once the new element has been fitted into the oven and the wires reconnected, reconnect the fasteners to the element.
Screw them down at the same locations and using the same screws as the previous element.
Be sure to tighten the screws so they hold the element securely.
Don’t screw the screws in so far that they crack or bend the element.
Turn on the power and test the element by turning on the oven.
After the new element has been secured, plug the oven back into the wall outlet.
Then, return the flow of power by switching the breaker back on.
Finally, turn on the oven to test that the new heating element is working.
Hold your hand over the element to feel if it is heating up.

Remove the screws from the bracket holding the igniter.

The igniter is supported by brackets that are screwed in.
Unscrew the screws and separate the brackets from the oven to dislodge the igniter.Tip: Keep the screws nearby so you don’t lose them.
Unplug the wire harness from the igniter and remove it.
After you’ve dislodged the brackets, you’ll be able to see the wire harness that is connected to the igniter and provides electricity to it.
Pull the igniter out a little bit so you can get a good grip on the wire harness and unplug the cords.
Then, pull the igniter out of the oven.
Plug the new igniter into the wire harness and insert the mounting screws.
Make sure the wires are attached securely and the igniter is in the same position as the faulty one that was removed.
Hold the igniter in place and attach the brackets by screwing in the screws.
Replace the bottom panel and install the screws to hold it in place.
Insert the front of the panel beneath the lip at the front of the bottom of the oven.
Then, lower the rear section of the panel back into place.
Insert the screws to hold the panel in place.
Be sure to tighten the screws so the panel is secure.
Plug in the oven and turn on the gas supply.
Now that the igniter has been replaced, plug in the gas range into the wall outlet.
Turn the dial on the gas supply to the “On” position.
If you had to move the oven to access the outlet and gas supply, return the oven back to its original position.
Turn the oven on to test that it’s working.
After you’ve restored power and the flow of gas to your gas oven, set the oven to a bake setting.
Use your hand to feel if the oven is heating up to confirm that the replaced igniter is functioning.
If the oven still doesn’t work, there may be an issue with the gas line, which requires a certified technician to repair.
Replacing an Oven Thermostat Unplug the oven before you begin to work on it.
The range of the oven and the thermostat use electricity to function.
To avoid the risk of accidental electrocution, make sure you unplug the oven before you do anything else.
The cord will be located behind the oven, so you may need to slide or pull the oven away from the wall to access it.
Use a 6 in (15 cm) length of string to pry off the thermostat knob.
If your oven has a knob that controls the thermostat, you need to remove it in order to replace the thermostat.
Use some string to slide beneath the knob, keep the string tight, and pry off the knob.
Don’t snap or jerk the knob off or you could damage it.
Keep the thermostat knob nearby so you can replace it when you’re finished.
Remove the screws from the upper back panel of the oven.
On the backside of the oven are panels that keep the internal components protected.
You need to remove the upper panel in order to access the faulty thermostat.
Locate the screws that hold the panel in place and remove them with a screwdriver.
Do not lose the screws!
Keep them nearby so you can put them back after you finish replacing the thermostat.
Pull the upper panel off of the oven.
Once you’ve removed the screws, allow the upper panel to lean off of the oven so you can grip it with your hands.
Lift the panel up and pull it away from the oven.
Use the opportunity to clean and wipe down the panel while you have it removed.
Place the panel nearby so you don’t lose it.
Unscrew the mounting screws from the thermostat and remove it.
If your oven has a thermostat knob, after you remove it, you’ll see 2 or 3 screws that keep the thermostat held in place.
Unscrew them with a screwdriver and remove the old thermostat from the back of the oven.Tip: Have another person hold the thermostat in place while you unscrew it from the front.
Install the new thermostat and screw it into place.
Once you’ve removed the faulty thermostat, place the new one in the same position as the old one.
Screw in the mounting screws to hold the new thermostat in place.
Don’t screw them so tight that they crack the mounts.
Wiggle the new thermostat to make sure it’s secure.
It shouldn’t move at all.
Transfer the wires from the old thermostat to the replacement.
With the new thermostat in place, pull out the wires from the old one and insert them in the same place on the new one.
Make sure they fit securely into the ports.
Some thermostats have clamps over the ports that you need to pinch open to insert the wires.
Unclip the old sensor and slide it out of the back of the oven.
Inside of the oven, there is a sensor bulb on the back wall.
Unclip it from the supports holding it in place and route it through the back of the oven.
Remove it from behind the oven.
Route the replacement sensor and clip it into position.
From the back of the oven, insert the new sensor bulb where you removed the old one.
Route the bulb to the inside of the oven.
Snap it back into the clips to hold it in place.
Replace the back panel and thermostat knob.
Put the upper back panel back to its original position and screw it into place.
Then, clip the thermostat knob back on if your oven has one.
It should “click” when it’s securely attached.
Turn the knob back and forth a few times to make sure it fits correctly.
Plug the oven back in and turn it on.
With the new thermostat and sensor bulb installed, you can restore power to the control panel by plugging the oven back in and sliding it back into position.
Test the new thermostat Test the new thermostat by turning the oven on to a specific temperature and placing an oven thermometer into the oven.
If the thermostat still isn’t working, there may be a deeper issue.
Call a technician to repair your oven.
Repairing an Oven Door Cut off the power and turn off the gas before you work.
Before you make any repairs on an oven, it’s very important that you eliminate the risk of electrocution or exposure to toxic gases.
Unplug your oven and shut off the gas valve if you have a gas oven.
Slide the oven away from the wall to unplug the cord and to allow you to access the rear of the oven.
Open the oven door and engage the locking mechanism.
Pull the handle to open the oven door all the way.
Look for a bracket near the hinge of the door.
Flick or swivel the bracket into position so the oven door remains open at a 45-degree angle.
Open the door all the way to engage the lock, then close the oven door until the locking mechanism prevents you from closing it.
Lift the oven door straight up to remove it.
With the lock engaged and the door at a 45-degree angle, grab the sides of the oven with your hands.
Gently slide the oven door straight up to remove it from the hinges.
Pull the door out of the oven.
Be careful not to drop the oven door or it break.
Place the door on a flat surface to work on.
It will be much easier for you to access the hinges and work on the oven door if you lay it flat on a table or a desk.
Clear the area so you can work unimpeded.
Lay down a towel or newspaper to prevent the door from scratching the surface.
Remove the screws from around the hinges and the side of the door.
There are 4 screws around each hinge that need to be removed.
You also need to remove the screws along the sides, top, and center of the door.
Be careful as you remove the screws because the door will start to come apart.
You don’t want to lose any pieces.
Keep all of the screws together so you don’t lose any of them.
Lift and remove the inner panel of the door.
Push the hinges up to raise the inner panel so you can get a grip on it with your hands.
Raise the inner panel to separate and remove it.
Pull out the hinges from each side of the door.
Lift up the internal panel of the door just enough for you to grab the hinge.
Gently slide the hinges out from the door and set them aside.
You may be able to scrap or sell the faulty hinges to a hardware store.
Place the new hinges in the channels.
After you’ve pulled out the old hinges, gently raise up the internal panel and insert the new hinges into the channels that held the old hinges.
They should fit neatly into place.
Lower the panel back down over the hinges.
Make sure you put the left and right hinges in the correct sides of the oven door.
Replace the inner door panel and replace all of the screws.
With the new hinges installed, put the door back together by lining up the inner panel and screwing it back into place.
Put the screws that were around the hinges back into place as well to secure the hinges.
Be sure to place the correct screws in the correct slots or it could weaken the integrity of the door.
Screw the panels together tightly so the door is held together securely.
Line up the hinge with the metal bracket of the oven and replace the door.
To replace the door on the oven, look for little notches on the hinges.
Line up the notches with the brackets on the oven and fit them into place.
Close the oven door to reattach it.
Open and close the oven door a few times to make sure it’s correctly aligned.
